{"comments": {"id": 26927, "count": 557, "talk_id": 2307}, "threadId": 26927, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "2307", "description": "Seventy thousand years ago, our human ancestors were insignificant animals, just minding their own business in a corner of Africa with all the other animals. But now, few would disagree that humans dominate planet Earth; we've spread to every continent, and our actions determine the fate of other animals (and possibly Earth itself). How did we get from there to here? Historian Yuval Noah Harari suggests a surprising reason for the rise of humanity.", "event": "TEDGlobalLondon", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Yuval Noah Harari: What explains the rise of humans?", "slug": "yuval_noah_harari_what_explains_the_rise_of_humans", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "2555", "slug": "yuval_noah_harari", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Yuval Noah", "lastname": "Harari", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Historian, author", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/a3683d72e78df0dfd69139688b14900ec498fc8f_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "In his book \"Homo Deus,\" Yuval Noah Harari explores the future of humankind: the destinies we may set for ourselves and the quests we'll undertake.", "whylisten": "

In his book, Homo Deus: A Brief History of Tomorrow, Yuval Noah Harari explores the projects, dreams and nightmares that will shape the 21st century -- from overcoming death to creating artificial life. He maps the future and asks fundamental questions: Where do we go from here? How will we protect this fragile world from our own destructive powers? The book has sold four million copies since its publication in 2016.

Harari's previous book, Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind, explores what made homo sapiens the most successful species on the planet. His answer: We are the only animal that can believe in things that exist purely in our imagination, such as gods, states, money, human rights, corporations and other fictions, and we have developed a unique ability to use these stories to unify and organize groups and ensure cooperation. Sapiens has sold eight million copies and been translated into more than 50 languages. Bill Gates, Mark Zuckerberg and President Barack Obama have recommended it as a must-read.

Harari lectures as a Professor of history at The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, where he specializes in world history, medieval history and military history. His current research focuses on macro-historical questions: What is the relationship between history and biology? What is the essential difference between Homo sapiens and other animals? Is there justice in history? Does history have a direction? Did people become happier as history unfolded? Harari has written for newspapers such as The Guardian, Financial Times, the Times, Nature magazine and the Wall Street Journal.

Harari's new book, 21 Lessons for the 21st Century, will take the pulse of our current global climate, focusing on the biggest questions of the present moment: What is really happening right now? What are today’s greatest challenges and choices? What should we pay attention to? The book will be published in multiple languages in September 2018.

In his book, Homo Deus: A Brief History of Tomorrow, Yuval Noah Harari explores the projects, dreams and nightmares that will shape the 21st century -- from overcoming death to creating artificial life. He maps the future and asks fundamental questions: Where do we go from here? How will we protect this fragile world from our own destructive powers? The book has sold four million copies since its publication in 2016.

Harari's previous book, Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind, explores what made homo sapiens the most successful species on the planet. His answer: We are the only animal that can believe in things that exist purely in our imagination, such as gods, states, money, human rights, corporations and other fictions, and we have developed a unique ability to use these stories to unify and organize groups and ensure cooperation. Sapiens has sold eight million copies and been translated into more than 50 languages. Bill Gates, Mark Zuckerberg and President Barack Obama have recommended it as a must-read.

Harari lectures as a Professor of history at The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, where he specializes in world history, medieval history and military history. His current research focuses on macro-historical questions: What is the relationship between history and biology? What is the essential difference between Homo sapiens and other animals? Is there justice in history? Does history have a direction? Did people become happier as history unfolded? Harari has written for newspapers such as The Guardian, Financial Times, the Times, Nature magazine and the Wall Street Journal.

Harari's new book, 21 Lessons for the 21st Century, will take the pulse of our current global climate, focusing on the biggest questions of the present moment: What is really happening right now? What are today’s greatest challenges and choices? What should we pay attention to? The book will be published in multiple languages in September 2018.

"}], "speaker_name": "Yuval Noah Harari", "tags": ["evolution", "history", "human origins", "humanity", "storytelling"], "title": "What explains the rise of humans?", "video_type": {"id": "1", "name": "TED Stage Talk"}, "viewed_count": 3855927}]}
author: Yuval Noah_Harari;
title: What explains the rise of humans?

aws-transcripts.transcript: 70,000 years ago, our ancestors were insignificant animals. The most important thing to know about price story humans is that they were unimportant. Their impact on the world was not much greater than that off jellyfish or five flies or woodpeckers. Today, in contrast, we control this planet. And the question is, how did we come from there to here? How did we turn ourselves from insignificant apes minding their own business in a corner off Africa, into the rulers off planet Earth? Usually we look for the difference between us and all the other animals. On the individual level, we want to believe I want to believe that there was something special about me about my body, about my brain that makes me so superior to a dog or a pig or a chimpanzee. But the truth is that on the individual level, I'm embarrassingly similar to a chimpanzee. And if you take me in a chimpanzee and put us together on some lonely island and we had to struggle for survival to see who survives better, I would definitely place my bets on the chimpanzee, not on myself, and this is not something wrong with me personally. I guess if they took almost any one of you and placed you alone with a chimpanzee on some island, the chimpanzee would do much better. The real difference between humans and all other animals is not on the individual level. It's on the collective level. Humans control the planet because they are the only animals that can cooperate both flexibly and in very large numbers. Now there are other animals, like the social insects, the bees, the ants that can cooperate in large numbers. But they don't do so flexibly. Their cooperation is very rigid. There is basically just one way in which a beehive can function in. If there is a new opportunity or in new danger, the bees cannot reinvent the social system overnight. They cannot, for example, execute the queen and establish a republic off bees or a communist dictatorship off worker bees. Other animals like the social mammals, the wolves, the elephants, the dolphins, the chimpanzees. They can cooperate much more flexibly. But they do so on Lee in small numbers because cooperation among chimpanzees is based on intimate knowledge, one off the other. If I'm a chimpanzee and you're a chimpanzee and I want to cooperate with you. I need to know you personally. What kind of chimpanzee are you? Are you a nice chimpanzee again? Evil chimpanzee? Are you trustworthy? If I don't know you, how can I cooperate with you? The only animals that can combine the two abilities together and cooperate both flexibly and still do so in very large numbers is us Homo sapiens. One versus one or even 10 versus 10. Chimpanzees might be better than us. But if you Pete 1000 humans against 1000 chimpanzees, the humans will win easily for the simple reason that 1000 chimpanzees cannot cooperate at all. And if you now try to cram 100,000 chimpanzees into Oxo Street or into Wembley Stadium or Tiananmen Square or the Vatican, you will get chaos complete Carol's Just imagine Wembley Stadium with 100,000 chimpanzees, complete mantis. In contrast, humans normally gather there in tens of thousands and what we get is not cares. Usually what we get is extremely sophisticated and effective networks off corporation. All the huge achievements off humankind throughout history, whether it's building the pyramids or flying to the moon, have been based not on the individual abilities. But on this ability to cooperate flexibly in large numbers, think even about this very talk that I'm giving now. I'm standing here in fund off on audience off about 300 or 400 people. Most off you are complete strangers to me. Similarly, I don't really know the people, all the people who have organized and worked on this event. I don't know the pilot and the crew members off the plane that brought me over here yesterday to London. I don't know the people who invented and manufactured this microphone and these cameras, which are recording what I'm saying. I don't know the people who wrote all the books and articles that I've read in preparation for this stock, and I certainly don't know all the people who might be watching this stock over the Internet somewhere in Buenos Iris or in New Delhi. Nevertheless, even though we don't know each other, we can work together to create this global exchange off ideas. This is something chimpanzees cannot do. They communicate off course, but you will never catch a chimpanzee traveling to some distant chimpanzee bend to give them a talk about bananas or about elephants or anything else that might interest chimpanzees. No corporation is, of course, not always nice. All the horrible things humans have been doing throughout history, and we have been doing some very horrible things. All those things are also based on large scale cooperation. Prisons are a system of cooperation. Slaughterhouses are a system of cooperation. Concentration camps are a system of cooperation. Chimpanzees don't have slaughterhouses and prisons and concentration camps. Now, supposed I've managed to convince you, perhaps that yes, we controlled the world because we can cooperate flexibly in large numbers. The next question that immediately arises in the mind off inquisitive listener is how exactly do we do it? What enables us alone off all the animals to cooperate in such a way? The answer is our imagination. We can cooperate flexibly with countless numbers off strangers because we alone off all the animals on the planet can create and believe fictions, fictional stories. And as long as everybody believes in the same fiction, everybody obeys and follows the same rules, the same norms, the same values. All other animals use their communication system on Lee to describe reality. A chimpanzee may say, Look, there is a lion. Let's run away or look, there is a banana tree over there. Let's go and get bananas. Humans, in contrast, used their language not merrily to describe reality, but also to create new realities. Fictional realities.
